item.title: Overlooked Drug Could Save Thousands Of Moms After Childbirth
item.description: April 26, 2017 - An inexpensive drug could dramatically reduce the number of deaths of mothers from bleeding after childbirth in low- and middle-income countries around the world.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 26, 2017 - An inexpensive drug could dramatically reduce the number of deaths of mothers from bleeding after childbirth in low- and middle-income countries around the world. http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/04/26/525639110/overlooked-drug-could-save-thousands-of-moms-after-childbirth

item.title: Shutdown Averted: White House Backs Down On Health Care Demands
item.description: April 26, 2017 - The White House appears to be backing down on multiple demands that were threatening a partial government shutdown, including withholding subsidies to help low-income people under Obamacare.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 26, 2017 - The White House appears to be backing down on multiple demands that were threatening a partial government shutdown, including withholding subsidies to help low-income people under Obamacare. http://www.npr.org/2017/04/26/525764683/shutdown-averted-white-house-backs-down-on-health-care-demands

item.title: Tyson Foods Promises Better Conditions And Safety For Meat Workers
item.description: April 26, 2017 - Meat-processing employs more than a half-million people. An investigation found they've got some of the most dangerous factory jobs in America and suffer from injury, low pay and lack of work breaks.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 26, 2017 - Meat-processing employs more than a half-million people. An investigation found they've got some of the most dangerous factory jobs in America and suffer from injury, low pay and lack of work breaks. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/04/26/525736888/tyson-foods-promises-better-conditions-and-safety-for-meat-workers

item.title: 'Minibrains' In A Dish Shed A Little Light On Autism And Epilepsy
item.description: April 26, 2017 - Experiments with small clusters of networked brain cells are helping scientists see how real brains develop normally, and what goes awry when cells have trouble making connections.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 26, 2017 - Experiments with small clusters of networked brain cells are helping scientists see how real brains develop normally, and what goes awry when cells have trouble making connections. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/04/26/525705550/minibrains-in-a-dish-shed-a-little-light-on-autism-and-epilepsy

item.title: How A Wild Berry Is Helping To Protect China's Giant Pandas And Its Countryside
item.description: April 26, 2017 - Long before it became a "superfood" in the U.S., schisandra was made into soups and jams and prized as a medicinal plant. Now the berry is at the center of a dramatic new approach to conservation.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 26, 2017 - Long before it became a "superfood" in the U.S., schisandra was made into soups and jams and prized as a medicinal plant. Now the berry is at the center of a dramatic new approach to conservation. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/04/26/525552957/how-a-wild-berry-helped-save-china-s-giant-pandas-and-its-countryside

item.title: Binge Drinkers Beware: Study Finds Link Between Alcohol And Heart Arrhythmias
item.description: April 26, 2017 - Researchers tested more than 3,000 people at Munich's Oktoberfest beer festival. They found getting drunk was associated with abnormal heart rhythms.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 26, 2017 - Researchers tested more than 3,000 people at Munich's Oktoberfest beer festival. They found getting drunk was associated with abnormal heart rhythms. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/04/26/525579920/binge-drinkers-beware-study-finds-link-between-alcohol-and-heart-arrhythmias

item.title: What This Doctor Is Going To Do With His $1 Million TED Prize
item.description:
April 25, 2017 - Raj Panjabi must use the award "to solve a timely, pressing problem." Here's what he plans to do.
- http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/04/25/525405868/what-this-doctor-is-going-to-do-with-his-1-million-ted-prize
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)

item.title: Cherokee Nation Sues Wal-Mart, CVS, Walgreens Over Tribal Opioid Crisis
item.description: April 25, 2017 - The tribe says these companies regularly filled large, suspicious prescriptions within the Nation's 14 counties in northeastern Oklahoma, leading to hundreds of tribal members' deaths.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 25, 2017 - The tribe says these companies regularly filled large, suspicious prescriptions within the Nation's 14 counties in northeastern Oklahoma, leading to hundreds of tribal members' deaths. http://www.npr.org/sections/codeswitch/2017/04/25/485887058/cherokee-nation-sues-wal-mart-cvs-walgreens-over-tribal-opioid-crisis

item.title: Psychiatrist Recalls 'Heartbreak And Hope' On Bellevue's Prison Ward
item.description: April 25, 2017 - Dr. Elizabeth Ford treated mentally ill inmates in New York City for more than a decade. It was almost universal, she says, that they had suffered abuse or significant neglect as children.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 25, 2017 - Dr. Elizabeth Ford treated mentally ill inmates in New York City for more than a decade. It was almost universal, she says, that they had suffered abuse or significant neglect as children. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/04/25/525533732/psychiatrist-recalls-heartbreak-and-hope-on-bellevues-prison-ward

item.title: Why China Is Selling Cheap HIV Tests In Campus Vending Machines
item.description: April 25, 2017 - It's a pilot project to reach youth who are at risk of infection — and reluctant to come to clinics because of the stigma around HIV/AIDS. Is anyone buying?
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 25, 2017 - It's a pilot project to reach youth who are at risk of infection — and reluctant to come to clinics because of the stigma around HIV/AIDS. Is anyone buying? http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/04/25/525380494/why-china-is-selling-cheap-hiv-tests-in-campus-vending-machines

item.title: Scientists Create Artificial Womb That Could Help Prematurely Born Babies
item.description: April 25, 2017 - The device kept fetal lambs alive for about a month, allowing them to continue to mature. It has not been tested in humans, and some say the device raises ethical questions.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 25, 2017 - The device kept fetal lambs alive for about a month, allowing them to continue to mature. It has not been tested in humans, and some say the device raises ethical questions. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/04/25/525044286/scientists-create-artificial-womb-that-could-help-prematurely-born-babies

item.title: Changes To Federal Insurance Plans Could Hurt Families Of Chronically Ill Kids
item.description: April 25, 2017 - Some urge ending funding to the Children's Health Insurance Program, and moving those 8 million kids to marketplace plans. But research shows the out-of-pocket costs to many families would soar.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 25, 2017 - Some urge ending funding to the Children's Health Insurance Program, and moving those 8 million kids to marketplace plans. But research shows the out-of-pocket costs to many families would soar. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/04/25/525475221/changes-to-federal-insurance-plans-could-hurt-families-of-chronically-ill-kids

item.title: Eat, Sleep, Repeat: How Kids' Daily Routines Can Help Prevent Obesity
item.description: April 25, 2017 - A new study finds that preschool-age children who didn't have a set sleep routine were more likely to be overweight by the time they hit the preteen years.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 25, 2017 - A new study finds that preschool-age children who didn't have a set sleep routine were more likely to be overweight by the time they hit the preteen years. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/04/25/525394739/eat-sleep-repeat-how-kids-daily-routines-can-help-prevent-obesity

item.title: What Fish Is Good For Me And The Planet? New Documentary Explores
item.description: April 24, 2017 - In order to investigate how eating fish affects our health as well as the oceans, author and fisherman Paul Greenberg spent a year eating fish every day.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 24, 2017 - In order to investigate how eating fish affects our health as well as the oceans, author and fisherman Paul Greenberg spent a year eating fish every day. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/04/24/525111293/what-fish-is-good-for-me-and-the-planet-new-documentary-explores

item.title: U.S. Tobacco Profits Soar Despite Drop In Number Of Smokers
item.description: April 24, 2017 - Despite a sharp decrease of smokers in the U.S., tobacco companies are more profitable than ever. NPR's Audie Cornish speaks with Jennifer Maloney of The Wall Street Journal about how cigarette companies have survived and thrived under tighter regulations.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 24, 2017 - Despite a sharp decrease of smokers in the U.S., tobacco companies are more profitable than ever. NPR's Audie Cornish speaks with Jennifer Maloney of The Wall Street Journal about how cigarette companies have survived and thrived under tighter regulations. http://www.npr.org/2017/04/24/525441653/u-s-tobacco-profits-soar-despite-drop-in-number-of-smokers
